source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_035_chunk7
evidence_span: Mechanical property data on zirconium hydride [32] show that below $7 0 0 ~ \mathrm { { K } }$ EPY $( 4 2 7 ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C } )$ zirconium hydride is a brittle material and above this temperature it exhibits increasing ductility with increasing temperature.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_035_chunk7
evidence_span: These high temperature tensile tests on hydrided zirconium containing 40 to 50.6 atomic percent hydrogen are judged to be a better representation of the mechanical properties of zirconium hydride than the rest of the more abundant data available for zirconium with lower levels of hydrogen (i.e., zirconium-hydride composites).

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_035_chunk8
evidence_span: A higher radial component of hydride orientation will result in a faster inward progress of the oxidation front into the metal than in the case of circumferential hydrides.

evidence_span: The occasional higher corrosion rates of RXA cladding compared to the SRA cladding may be related to the higher $f _ { N }$ for RXA cladding.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_035_chunk8
evidence_span: The occasional higher corrosion rates of RXA cladding compared to the SRA cladding may be related to the higher $f _ { N }$ for RXA cladding.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_035_chunk8
evidence_span: In a "banded" hydride structure, the hydride free regions will slow down the progress of the oxidation front into the metal and thereby slow the acceleration of the corrosion process.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_035_chunk8
evidence_span: These data show a smaller loss of ductility of zirconium alloys with isolated hydride agglomerates compared to specimens with a uniform hydride precipitate distribution for identical hydrogen contents.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_035_chunk9

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_035_chunk9
evidence_span: a structure with the majority of grain boundaries orientated parallel to the oxidation front (e.g., an SRA structure with elongated grains oriented with their long axis parallel to the tube outer surface) is expected to have a better long-term corrosion resistance

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_035_chunk9
evidence_span: a structure containing more grain boundary surfaces perpendicular to the oxidation front (e.g., an equiaxed grain structure of RXA cladding with a random orientation of grain boundaries) is expected to have a worse long-term corrosion resistance

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_035_chunk10
evidence_span: Considering hydride ductility and precipitate location, a water autoclave test at $6 3 3 ~ \mathrm { K }$ with appropriate heat flux is expected to show better correlation with in-PWR corrosion performance than tests done at higher temperatures or without heat flux.
